thread.title: News roundup: Clinton advisers prep for an election landslide
thread.title_full: News roundup: Clinton advisers prep for an election landslide | The Salt Lake Tribune

author: Tribune Political Reporters
title: News roundup: Clinton advisers prep for an election landslide

organizations.name: centers for disease control and prevention
university of utah’s hinckley institute of politics

text:
Clinton advisers prep for a landslide election. Pence hits Utah to raise cash, assure Utah win. McMullin vies for Utah votes.

Happy Friday. We have 66 days to election, folks, and advisers to Hillary Clinton’s campaign have identified so many paths to an Election Day victory they are now focusing not only on the one or two battlegrounds that would ensure a win but on opening up the possibility of an Electoral College landslide. [ Politico ]

Topping the news: GOP vice presidential candidate Mike Pence touted school vouchers and state and local control over education in a speech at the Utah Solutions Summit Thursday morning. [ Trib ] [ DNews ] [ ABC4 ] [ KUER ]

-> Utah native and independent presidential candidate Evan McMullin claimed that he entered the race to give voters a more reasonable conservative option during a speech at the University of Utah’s Hinckley Institute of Politics on Thursday. [ Trib ]

-> The Utah Republican Party has chosen not to appeal a court decision upholding SB54, a law that allows candidates to gather signatures to get on the party’s primary ballot. The Chair of the party is confident that the 2017 legislature can address the problems they have with the bill. [ Trib ]

Tweets of the day: From @ Patbagley : "By coincidence @mike_pence and Star Wars’ Mark Hamill are speaking in same building. One is way into science fiction #TrickleDown"

From @ ryanbeckwith : "It’s almost like Hillary Clinton has some experience or skill in asking people for money."

From @ mikandynothem : "In 2016, @realDonaldTrump has held more press conferences in Mexico than Hillary has in America."

Happy Birthday: Today to state Rep. Becky Edwards and on Saturday to Trib photographer Scott Sommerdorf.

Tune In: Tribune reporters Matt Canham, Chris Smart and Sean P. Means as well as editorial writer George Pyle join the Tribune’s Benjamin Wood to talk about the week’s top stories, including incumbent Rep. Mia Love and opponent Doug Owens’ campaigns for congress, homeless services in the Salt Lake valley and Salt Lake Comic Con.

In other news: After a massive bond proposal that was rejected in 2013, Jordan School District has cut costs and proposed a new $245 million bond, half the size of the previous one, to relieve overcrowding in the district’s schools. The Utah Taxpayers Association does not plan to oppose the measure. [ Trib ] 

-> An herbal drug called Kratom, legal in Utah, is about to be banned by the Drug Enforcement Administration, which classifies it in the same category as heroin. [ KUTV ] [ Fox13 ]

-> The adult obesity rate in Utah has gone down, but the problem still persists with a rate over 20 percent, according to data released Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. [ Trib ]

-> Preston Barlow, one of the FLDS men awaiting trial for food stamp fraud, has been granted permission by a judge to write letters to imprisoned FLDS leader Warren Jeffs. [ Trib ] [ DNews ]

-> Three nominees to replace a retiring judge in Utah’s 2nd District Court have been announced. [ Trib ]

-> The LDS Church announced a $2 million donation to the refugee cause. [ KUTV ]

-> Pat Bagley offers his take on the effects of elephant poaching. [ Trib ]

Nationally: Hillary Clinton raised $143 million in August alone, indicating solid readiness for swing state spending in the final months of the election. [ NYTimes ] [ WaPost ] [ CNN ] [ Time ] [ Politico ]

-> The State Department has announced it will release Clinton’s meeting schedules from her time as Secretary of State before the election in November rather than after. The schedules will respond to an Associated Press story indicating that donations to the Clinton Foundation bought people meetings with Clinton. [ CNN ] [ Politico ] [ Time ]

-> Donald Trump has hired David Bossie, president of Citizens United, as his deputy campaign manager. [ WaPost ] [ Politico ]

-> Sen. Tim Kaine defended Clinton amidst talk of her unavailability to the media. Clinton has not held a press conference since December 5, 2015. [ ABCNews ] [ CNNMoney ]

-> Several prominent Latino Trump supporters have called it quits after Wednesday’s immigration speech, one even saying that he thinks the speech will lose Trump the election. [ NBCNews ] [ Politico ] [ WaPost ] [ NYTimes ]

-> Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto and Trump differ in their descriptions of what happened in their Wednesday meeting in Mexico City. Peña Nieto says he refused to pay for a border wall; Trump says they didn’t discuss it. [ NBCNews ] [ CNN ]

Where are they? 

Rep. Chris Stewart meets with Cedar City residents, talks to students at Iron Springs Elementary, visits the Iron County Fair and addresses the crowd at Hurricane Peach Days. 
Gov. Gary Herbert sits down with U.S. Department of Homeland Security Director Eric Patterson. 
Lt. Gov. Spencer Cox heads to the Hurricane Peach Days celebration. 
State Auditor John Dougall participates in a teleconference to discuss enhanced fraud detection tools. 

Got a tip? A birthday, wedding or anniversary to announce? Email us at cornflakes@sltrib.com . If you haven’t already, sign up for our weekday email and get this sent directly to your inbox. [ Trib ]

-- Thomas Burr and Zoe Woolf McGinn
Twitter.com/thomaswburr and Twitter.com/zoewmcginn
